project: Simple Biogas Production System for Cooking Fuel
concept: To design and implement a small-scale anaerobic digestion system converting organic waste (e.g., animal manure, kitchen scraps) into biogas for use as cooking fuel in rural or peri-urban settings in Nigeria, focusing on sustainability, cost-effectiveness, and ease of maintenance.
research: Optimal C:N ratio for local feedstocks (e.g., cow dung, food waste)
Digester volume calculation based on household needs and available feedstock
Biogas yield estimation and methane content analysis
H2S and CO2 scrubbing methods suitable for small scale
Safety standards for biogas handling and usage
Local material sourcing and construction techniques
Community engagement strategies for adoption and maintenance
goals: Produce sufficient biogas (e.g., 2-4 mÂ³/day) for a typical household's daily cooking needs
Reduce reliance on traditional biomass fuels (wood, charcoal) and LPG
Mitigate greenhouse gas emissions from organic waste decomposition
Provide a sustainable waste management solution for organic residues
Improve indoor air quality and health outcomes for users
Demonstrate a replicable, low-cost energy model adaptable to local conditions

problems_overall.problem: Inconsistent biogas production due to feedstock variability.
problems_overall.suggested_solution: Implement standardized feedstock preparation protocols and regular feeding schedules. Consider co-digestion of multiple waste streams for a more balanced nutrient input.

problems_overall.problem: Biogas leakage and odor issues from poorly sealed systems.
problems_overall.suggested_solution: Ensure proper sealing of all connections, regular inspection for leaks using soapy water, and adequate ventilation in the digester vicinity. Use high-quality, durable materials for gas lines.

problems_overall.problem: High H2S content in raw biogas causing corrosion and potential health risks.
problems_overall.suggested_solution: Integrate a simple H2S scrubber (e.g., packed bed with iron filings or steel wool) post-digester and pre-usage to reduce sulfide levels.

problems_overall.problem: Limited technical expertise for system installation, maintenance, and troubleshooting at the local level.
problems_overall.suggested_solution: Provide comprehensive, hands-on training to local users and technicians. Develop a simple, visual maintenance guide and establish a local support network.

decision_matrix.from: Organic waste (e.g., animal manure, kitchen scraps)

options.name: Manual Shredding & Mixing
options.why_it_works: Relies on human labor for simple mechanical reduction and mixing with water, requiring no power.
pros: Easy to implement with basic tools

options.name: Mechanical Shredder & Mixer (Motorized)
options.why_it_works: Utilizes a motor-driven blade or pump system to efficiently shred and mix feedstock with water, creating a uniform slurry.
features: Requires power source (electricity or small engine)
pros: Improved digester efficiency due to uniform feedstock
cons: Requires power, which may be intermittent
options.availability: Moderate (some models available locally, specialized units may need import)

options.name: Fixed-Dome Digester
options.why_it_works: An underground, rigid, airtight concrete or brick structure where anaerobic digestion occurs, with an integrated gas storage space above the slurry level.
cons: Leaks are difficult to detect and repair
options.estimated_cost: High (NGN 500,000 - 1,500,000 depending on size and materials)
options.availability: High (construction materials and skills are widely available in Nigeria)

options.name: Floating-Drum Digester
options.why_it_works: Consists of a cylindrical tank with a separate, movable steel or plastic drum that floats on the slurry, collecting biogas and indicating gas volume.
options.availability: Medium (metal fabrication skills common, specialized drums less so)

options.name: Balloon Digester (Flexible Bag)
options.why_it_works: A simple, portable plastic or rubber bag that contains the slurry and collects the biogas, expanding as gas is produced.
pros: Very easy and fast to install
cons: Susceptible to physical damage (punctures, UV degradation)
options.availability: High (plastic/PVC materials available, pre-made bags can be sourced)

options.name: Water Scrubber
options.why_it_works: Biogas is bubbled through water, which absorbs some CO2 and H2S due to their solubility, and also removes water vapor.
pros: Low cost and easy to construct
cons: Does not remove all CO2 or H2S
May require a pump if not gravity-fed

options.name: Iron Filings/Chips Adsorption (for H2S)
options.why_it_works: Biogas passes through a bed of iron filings (e.g., steel wool, iron sponge) where H2S reacts with iron to form iron sulfides, removing H2S.
pros: Low operating cost (iron filings are cheap)
cons: May be less efficient at very high H2S concentrations
options.estimated_cost: Low (NGN 5,000 - 15,000 for filter housing and media)
options.availability: High (scrap metal, steel wool widely available)

options.name: Activated Carbon Filter (for H2S & some VOCs)
options.why_it_works: Activated carbon has a porous structure that adsorbs H2S and other trace impurities and volatile organic compounds (VOCs) from the biogas.
features: Requires regeneration or replacement of carbon
pros: Highly effective for H2S and other impurities
cons: Higher initial cost for activated carbon
Carbon needs periodic replacement or regeneration
options.estimated_cost: Moderate (NGN 30,000 - 80,000 for unit and initial carbon)
options.availability: Medium (activated carbon can be sourced from industrial suppliers)

options.name: Direct Pipeline to Biogas Burner
options.why_it_works: Biogas is transported directly from the purification unit to a single biogas-compatible stove burner via a low-pressure pipeline.
cons: Limited to a single usage point
Pressure may fluctuate based on digester type
Not ideal for multiple appliances or distant usage
options.availability: High (PVC/HDPE pipes, biogas burners increasingly available locally)

options.name: Low-Pressure Regulator & Distribution Manifold
options.why_it_works: A pressure regulator stabilizes the biogas pressure, and a manifold then distributes it to multiple outlets, each potentially with an individual valve.
cons: Higher initial cost due to regulator and manifold
Requires proper sizing of regulator and pipes
options.availability: Medium (biogas regulators and manifolds becoming more available from specialized suppliers)

skills: Biochemical Engineering (anaerobic digestion kinetics, feedstock optimization), Mechanical Engineering (digester design, piping, gas handling, burner selection), Civil Engineering (digester construction, site preparation, structural integrity), Environmental Engineering (waste management, emissions control, digestate handling), Safety Engineering (gas handling, pressure systems, leak detection).
